I had to spend a couple of hours in class learning what security measures were needed, then certify that I had a secure place to store them overnight. It was not what you might think when you say Moon rocks. It was a sealed Lucite disc with six small flecks about a quarter inch or smaller in size arranged in a circle. They were indexed with information on when, what mission, and where they were picked up on the Moon.

The amazing new addition, though, was that ABOVE the moon rock, there was a picture FROM THE MOON showing THAT PRECISE ROCK. Andrea Mosie, I can't imagine that happening without your input. My grandfather was a civil engineer who started in the navy (and coincidentally was on the ship that recovered John Glenn after his first space flight) and eventually went on to work on the bay bridge in between Oakland and San Franciscan after the 89' earthquake and At&t park, home of the Sf Giants MLB team, but by far the coolest thing he ever worked on was the Lunar Penetrometer, the instrument that was used to take samples of the lunar surface (I'm not sure what missions exactly, I would need to dig through storage to find out) but anyways, growing up whenever I was at his house I would notice this glass urn looking thing filled with grey rocks on a bookshelf, for the longest time I never asked about them, he was an engineer in the SF Bay Area and would talk your ear off about different types of bedrock if you let him, so I just never asked until I was about 11 or 12, when I brought it up while he was watching a golf tournament, he never liked people bugging him while he watched golf, but weirdly he turned off the tournament, grabbed the vase and took out one of the rocks, sat me down at the table and put it in my hands. He let me turn it over in my hands a few times, and it felt a little strange but nothing too crazy. I was confused, what's the big deal, why was he and my mom staring at me so intensely? Well, I'm sure you figured it out by now, it was one of the rocks taken from the moon with the device he and his team designed. When he told me I was hit with a truly indescribable wave of emotion, mostly pride and love for my fellow humans, sitting there holding that unassuming rock and thinking about the history of our species, the obstacles we've overcome, and seemingly impossible feats of science and engineering that allowed some of the bravest among us to fly out 250,000 miles to another celestial body and bring that rock to earth and eventually to my young little hands, and inspire me to, from that point on,  to think there's nothing we can't over come if we stop hating each other and start to work together and be good to each other. its stuff like that that get me through years like these so long after

Last year on July 16 2019, I was fortunate to be working on a lunar rock sample from Apollo 11 in collaboration with a geologist. Amazingly coincidental, that also happened to be the 50th anniversary of the Apollo 11 launch to the day, where they collected the moon rock in which our thin slice originated. It was one of those rare "wow, my job is awesome sometimes" moments. However, even I didn't know how complex and rigorous the handling and categorization of the rocks was, until just now.
Serious question: Why is it so important to study these rocks? Before answering please consider the government poured vast amounts of money into this.

NASA-The composition of the Moon is much like that of the Earth. Its rocks are similar to Earth rocks . However, the Moon has no atmosphere, it shows no trace of past or present life, and its rocks contain no water


NASA-The isotopes of oxygen that exist on the moon are the same as those that exist on Earth, so it was difficult if not impossible to tell the difference between water from the moon and water from Earth


NASA-The moon rocks were analyzed for signs of water bound to minerals present in the rocks; while trace amounts of water were detected, these were assumed to be contamination from Earth, because the containers the rocks came back in had leaked.

Destin: “I love laminar flow.”

I used to work in Sandia Laboratories’ MESA facility and our clean rooms were the first laminar flow clean rooms in the world. The ceiling and floor were grills and fresh scrubbed clean air was constantly raining down on you and being sucked out at your feet. Our bunny suits had helmets with battery-powered scrubbers attached to prevent the particulates from your face from falling off and contaminating the product. Very cool stuff.

The presentation rocks went on display in museums, libraries, scientific institutions and government offices. Within 30 years though, as if the moon had lost its glow, public interest in moon rocks waned. By 2002, 159 of the rocks were unaccounted for. Many of them vanished because of faulty record-keeping, but some disappeared due to political intrigue or eluded notice in private collections and the black market. One, remarkably, went to a landfill. Although unofficially upset at the casual handling of the samples, NASA could not look for items that didn’t belong to the agency anymore. What are the odds? At the age of 54 (feeling quite old), I am starting to realise that I am actually one of the youngest people alive to actually remember watching Armstrong and Aldrin land on the moon. I was just 4 years old at the time and my scientist father got me and my brother out of bed to watch the event (this was after midnight in the UK). My brother, who is just 11 months younger than me doesn't remember the event. I guess that everybody who remembers this on TV is my age (54) or older, and bearing in mind the number of people on the Earth at the time who actually had access to live television, there probably aren't that many of us left who have first-hand experience of it. It makes me feel honoured.

I was, however, VERY lucky to see some real moon dust a couple of years later because my father's research facility here in the UK was granted access to some and we queued up for quite some time in order to see it (people who queue for Disneyland rides will appreciate the type of queue). I still remember it to this day, nearly 50 years later. There wasn't much of it, and it was behind a very thick glass lens (probably under a vacuum considering the thickness of the glass - sadly Dad died over 25 years ago so I can't ask him more about it). And as a kid, I had to stand on a small block to see it. This would have been about 1970 or 1971.

My father analyzed the samples from Apollo 11 while working under contract for NASA at the University of North Carolina back in 1970.  I asked how much he got to experiment with...he said he got about 1/2 of a match head's worth.  From that he ran many experiments(as an analytic chemist) and found that they're almost geologically identical to Columbia River basalt(Washington State).  He always kinda laughs about all the security...he said they really have no more "secrets" to give past the first couple of years worth of testing.  They're really pretty basic rocks.

I used to work in Building 37 which is almost next door to this moon rock facility at the NASA Johnson Space Center. Today Building 37 is used for biomedical research, but it was the original quarantine building for the returning Apollo astronauts, the moon rocks, and their return capsules. Just in case there were moon bugs, nobody knew then and they were playing it safe. The astronauts actually stayed in a modified Airstream trailer just outside the building while the return capsule and moon rocks were processed indoors inside a giant vacuum chamber. I think the chamber had about a 30 foot ceiling, was maybe 30 feet wide and 100 feet long, more or less, to give an idea of the scale, those are by no means exact numbers. The vacuum held any potential contaminants inside and helped to prevent any contamination of the returned samples. There was quite extensive processing done there, most of which is probably lost to history; for example the return capsule was filthy with moon dust and I don't know what they did with that, but it's probably being curated as shown in this video with the rest of the moon rocks. Which is where everything got moved after processing in Building 37. After Apollo ended and Building 37 was repurposed, the vacuum chamber was converted into lab space for the Cardiovascular Laboratory of NASA's Space Biomedical Research Institute, which is where I did my postdoc work on cardiovascular countermeasures to the headward fluid shifts astronauts experience in microgravity, and why I know a little bit about this step in the processing of the moon rocks before they got to where they are today.


One day I got to take a tour of the moon rock facility shown in this video, bunny suit and all, with a small group of maybe a dozen people. We didn't get quite the VIP treatment these guys did with getting their hands into the box gloves, but it was close. We were briefed very professionally about the history and purposes of the facility, and were shown around the area of the glove boxes and cutting enclosure. We did not go into the Vault though, it was closed tight. When our guide ended her talk we were invited to look around on our own, and I chose to examine the interiors of some of the glove boxes very closely. I was astounded to see in one of them, a hair. Just a short piece maybe 2 or 3 inches long. To be fair it might have come from a cleaning brush or some kind of other tool like that deliberately introduced into the box, although it was not straight but somewhat curly so I don't think so. When I pointed out the hair to our guide she became quite embarrassed and flustered about it, and turned our attention elsewhere. I think she might have headed the place at the time (1990), but I'm not sure about that. It was one of the more amusing experiences during my time there :-)

On a similar note, I assume that the composition of the surface has to be pretty stable since they were exposed for ages and ages, but is it possible that the insides of the samples could contain compounds that could sublimate when exposed? Way back in the 70's.. I was in high school..WE went on a field trip to Chicago museum of science and industry..I went on my own..I was in a area with old artifacts in these huge lights glass cases,,Every so often their was a space between the cases..So I walked through the space behind these cases..It was dark in the room..Only the cases where lighted..So as I walked behind the cases..A narrow walk way..I saw a light coming from a door to a room..Now I knew that they were setting up for the moon rocks.Our school screwed up the dates..I slowly opened the door..Nobody was in there..So I walked in the well lighted room..And there they were Moon rocks..About ten..Very small..So I looked at them lying open and picked up every one of them..They were light in weight and gray..I knew they could crumble and I put them back..I thought of talking one..But figured I would get busted..So, I got my best friend and he followed me to the room..And we looked at everything there..No cards or cases ..Just ten moon rocks..I wonder if Dewayne remembers that..Every time still..When I hear moon rock..I think of that day..I should of took them all..But they would of crumbled in my pocket..I know I would of been busted for sure..It was in the 70's there weren't any cameras..I still can see those rocks..
I never told anybody except Dewayne..He also thought of take them too..The rocks were the first that came back from the moon..I did not think abouty DNA back then..So my DNA is on those rocks..I was a thrill to find them and hold..So, Now the 1.1 million people know.. I am saddened that science is turning into dogma like a church - filled with devout believers - priest classes (Elon Musk, Neil DeGrass Tyson, SmarterEveryDay, Bill Nye) instead of what it is supposed to be. . Interesting, now I'm not sure if I've held a moon rock or not. Back in the 80s there was a former NASA scientist/physicist who gave a two hour talk on the moon landings etc. He had 2 interesting items that we passed around, one was (or claimed to be) a moon rock, and he had the photos of it on the lunar surface.
The other (more interesting item) was a metal bar made of Titanium, it was so light it felt like it was a hollow pipe, and it was (or at least claimed to be) off the apollo 11 lander (the eagle) and had been connected to the shock absorbers on one of the landing legs. The story went that this rod was made by layering Titanium crystals in interlocking layers, and given how many attempts it took to make each rod, they had cost over a million dollars each back in the 60s.......by the 80s they were much cheaper to make and were commonly used on aircraft landing gear. This rod had been removed and brought back to Earth to check how well it had held up to the landing, and when the engineers had finished with it, they threw it in the trash, where this physicist then retrieved it after being told where it was.

Ok, this is awesome. For more than one reason, but for me personally...

I had recently this year met Andrea at one of the Houston Symphony Orchestra free concerts they put on at various high schools around the Houston area. This year the HSO's theme was Space, and Andrea and her two cohorts at NASA were there in collaboration with HSO, and with various samples. Such a lovely person and lovely people overall! Being the science-y type of guy (astronaut wannabe when I was young!) I was very much happy to chat with them all about the samples, how they formed, how they got them (I mean, a Mars rock didn't come here the way you'd think...) what happens to samples (which I found interesting that if they're NOT destructively tested, they're sent back from where they were sent to! Recycling is important, if they don't have to slice off another piece, that preserves the overall samples!) and just had a lovely, way too short and way too monopolistic time with them.

And then I heard the best Symphony in the world perform space related-ish music, starting with Also Sprach Zarathustra and ending with ET: The Extra Terrestrial - Chase/Saying Goodbye (which has another story re: John Williams and Steven Spielberg.)

I'm just so tickled to see this video. Thanks, Dustin, Andrea, her teammates and NASA!

To all those doubters and conspiracy theorists out there, particularly those who think a moon rock was a piece of petrified wood...

Australia, which was an integral part of the moon landing communications systems and actually provided the televised link of Neil Armstrong's first steps on the moon to the US via the Honeysuckle Creek radiotelesope facility (wrongly but humorously identified as the Parkes facility in the movie 'The Dish'), has a moon rock on public display at the Canberra Deep Space Centre, aka Tidbinbilla.

Australian scientists have independently attested that samples provided to Australian institutions are not from earth and are lunar in origin and that the signal received by Honeysuckle Creek came from the moon and not someone's back yard. Scientists from many other countries have also attested to the authenticity of moon rock samples, including some countries which do not have the US's best interest at heart and would love the chance to humiliate the nation. None have.

By the way, find the movie, it's a gentle and very funny 'poke' at highly qualified scientists.

When I was in 6th grade in 1969, our family moved to TX as my dad went to work for NASA for Apollo.
It was a really cool place to grow up. I was regularly on site. My dad worked on the team that developed the photographic mapping techniques they used to map the moon.
One weekend he included me in one of his experiments on the "rock pile" - the simulated lunar surface at JSC (no longer there). I ran the surveyors level to record "ground truth" measurements that he would later use to compare "measurements" he made from areal photographs he took from a helicopter. A really super experience with my did that I will never forget.

So cool! I remember seeing the 1st moon walk on our black/white t.v. Yes, I'm old. My parents hosted a cookout and veiwing party. The guests were mostly my Dad's co-workers (they were all engineers) and their families. I was only 4 1/2 yrs old and didn't understand the magnitude of what we were watching. But all the adults were blown away. Some were even emotional. That experience of wonder, with all those people packed into our living room, has stuck with me.

A couple years later, NASA sent a few of the moon rocks on a "tour" to public schools. I got to see one up close. It was protected in a small glass case.

Thank you for taking us on this adventure. 🤩
